Radar Theory and Analysis¶

Definitions¶

Capacity

Capacitance is “the amount of charge a material can hold” for a given applied voltage

Electric Permitivity

resistance of matter to an electric field

Relative Electric Permitivity

The relative permittivity defines the dielectric properties of a material relative to that of free-space

Dielectric permittivity

This physical property quantifies how easily material becomes polarized in the presence of an electric field.

Dielectric Constant

usually 1 in a vacuum, but depends on material structure

Relative Dielectric Constant

Radio Waves¶

  • depends on the speed of light in free space ( 300.000 km / s)

  • the relative electric constant

  • the relative magnetic permeability ( 1 for non magnetic materials)

  • for GPR purposes we often consider only dielectric permittivity (e) to influence velocity

Reflections

  • depends on the contrast in dielectric constant (value of dielectric permittivity) of adjacent layers

  • the higher → more energy is reflected

Attenuation

Attenuation dictates how deep we can see, and is usually described in terms of a “skin depth”. Skin depth is the depth at which the field strength falls to 1/2.71828 (or 1/e) of its original amplitude.

Scattering

Mie scattering…

is scattering of energy in a random matter for objects of the same wavelength as the radar signal

Rayleigh scattering…

occurs when objects are smaller than the radar wavelength and produce ‘clutter’ noise

Absorbtion

turning electromagnetic energy into heat
